DR. F. E. BAMBERGER
RETURNS FROM TOUR
OF WESTERN STATES
Studied Capability Of Children In Academic
Courses
SPOKE TO ASSEMBLY
IN WASHINGTON
Tour Was Made During
The Election
Period

Dr. Florence E. Bamberger, Professor of Education at Johns Hopkins University, chairman of the
Board of the College for Teachers,
recently returned from a tour of the
Western states, has found that the
general consensus of educational
opinion prevalent in the territory
included in her itinerary, is that
children incapable of mastering
academic courses should be given
vocational courses in their place.
By actual test, it has been proved
that although some pupils must attend school they are unable to receive passing grades in many academic subjects. Therefore, it is held
necessary for schools to include in
their curricula such vocational subjects as shop, and above all, music
and art to take care of these students.

which they are capable of
On All American Dance Eleven subjects
handling, and thus they will not take
Subjects Can Be Mastered

up the time of the teacher, leaving
her free to devote her entire time to
the other students which are interested in and can handle academic
subjects.
Dr. Bamberger was invited to
make the tour and to address eight
audiences by the Washington Association. After speaking in Washington, where she was received very
enthusiastically, she proceeded to
Portland, Oregon, at the request of
the Administrative Council, and the
Organization of
City School
Teachers.
Proposed Reform Measures

Made at election time, the tour
revealed to Dr. Bamberger several
proposed reform measures which
were being considered at that time.
Many states have initiative and referendum, and on Election Day an
initiative bill for a graded income
tax was referred to the people of
Washington, which also has a proposed equalization bill, to make the
tax more just by placing the heavier taxes on the wealthier counties.

The motion which was brought
up at the S.A.C. meeting Wednesday and which wil be voted on at
the next meeting to be held next
week reads:
Motion Brought Up

Students only in the College
of Arts and Sciences, School of
Engineering, and School of
Business Economics shall be
eligible for offices in•and membership in activities represented
in the Student Activities Council; any member of these three
schools who is expelled from
the University for any reason
by action of Student Council or
University officials shall automatically lose any post held in
any activity; and under the
New Plan a student shall be
eligible for office or membership until the completion of his
fourth year of undergraduate
residence.
This motion, if passed next
week, will automatically bar from
campus activities all students in
the College for Teachers and all
graduate students not under the
New Plan. Last April, the Council ruled out women from membership in Hopkins activities, but
this new ruling will bar both male
and female students n the College
for Teachers.
Not Part Of Undergrad School

It was pointed out that the College for Teachers is not regarded
as a part of the undergraduate
department q the University,
which officially consists 'of the
A.B., engineering, and business
economics schools, all of which
are exclusively male. Inasmuch
as the Student Activities Council
controls all campus activities in
the three undergraduate schools
and inasmuch as College for
Teachers and graduate students
do not pay the required ten-dollar
activities fee annually, it was decided to make a definite ruling as
to eligibility in Hopkins student
organizations governed by the
S.A.C.

Richard M. Haywood
Replaces Dr. Mustard
As a result of the death of Dr.
W. P. Mustard, formerly of the
Johns Hopkins University faculty,
Dr. Richard M. Haywood, also of
the University will take charge of
the former's Latin classes. Dr.
Haywood, who resides in Baltimore, received his Ph.D. from this
University in June, 1932.

Popularity Contest
AGAIN The Hullabaloo will conduct
its annual contest for the most popular
men in the freshman, sophomore, and
junior classes. Again, even for this obviously insignificant poll, politics will take
its place. Although we cannot see the
necessity for this popularity contest, we
ask that, if it is to be made actually
representative and fair, that every member of the three classes concerned cast his
ballot for the man whom he beleives deserves a place in the list of popular
undergraduates.
In the past, the contest was participated in by a decidedly small percentage
of each class. We urge that every freshman, sophomore, and junior vote for the
man in his class whom he believes has
done the most for his class and who is
generally regarded as a well-liked fellow.
The Hullabaloo editors should declare the
vote invalid if it is found that less than
two-thirds of each class casts ballots.

To the Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
I didn't agree with your editorial of November 4th. entitled
THE SURPRISE PACKAGE.
I had just finished a week of allnight sessions getting our magazine out on time, and let me tell
you it is one hell of a job. Its hard
for a raw editor to publish a publication for the first time especially with a new printing company.
I have just been through the mill
and I think you jumped on Miss
Howser a little too hard in your
editorial. If you could see how
generally "lousey" and machined
are the average run of publications, you would appreciate the
high standard of work that Miss
Howser has produced.
• As the publication of a magazine falls on the shoulders of one
person, as the editor has to go to
school as well as get it out, and as
Miss Howser had a number of
clever and novel features in the
magazine, I think your editorial
should have been one of encouragement and commendation instead of what it was.
Another thing. Even though the
publications here seem to habitusually disagree with your editorials,
still, I admire a person who comes
out and says what he thinks. The
University is never the loser when
such a person occupies the editor's chair. So here's to your editorial page—long may it rave.
CLARK HEIRONIMUS,
Editor, University of
Maryland Old Line.

By MILLARD LANGFELD, JR.

Baltimore theatergoers have indeed been favored in the succession
of fine productions which have
graced the boards of Ford's Theater
in recent months, but with the advent of Show Boat, which opens
there Monday evening for a run of
one week, the acme of entertainment values has been reached.
Taking form under the personal
supervision of that master showman, the late Florenz Ziegfeld, this
lovely musical fantasy is an adaptation of Edna Ferber's great novel
by the same name, and has been left
intact as originally conceived by him.

Marshall College maintains that a
girl covers up three-quarters of
her personality when she wears a
coat.

A co-ed at Bucknell, in answer
to a question as to the identity of
Karl Marx, stammered;"He must
be the fellow who plays the harp,
isn't he?"

The Lehigh Brown and White
contains the following news item:
A student came to Wetherford
College in Texas with a herd of
cows, pastured them behind the
dormitory, and is meeting expenses
by selling the milk to his fellow
students.
At Creighton University an effective way of getting students
to class on time was accidently discovered by a janitor. He unwittingly placed a dearth of chairs in
a classroom, resulting in students
hurrying to class early in order to
obtain a seat.

Although Rudy Vallee may be
the idol of many girls, he certainly
is not popular with the co-eds at
the School of Education at Western Reserve University. A recent
beauty contest over which he was
to be judge had to be called off because of lack of interest in the
judge on the part of the girls. "I
think somebody else would be
better fitted for the job" was the
comment made by the head of the
student council.

Students of the Johns Hopkins
University who act in a manner
unbecoming gentTemen at the
dances sponsored by the Cotillion
Board and held in Levering Hall are
to be called before Student Council, it was announced yesterday.
It was indicated that on the
first offense, the student will probably be warned by Student Council to act gentlemanly in the future at the weekly dances in Levering. However, on the second offense, it was said, suspension of
the student will probably be ordered
by the Council.
The reason for this move was
not given, but it is believed that it
came in the wake of a recent incident in Levering Hall in which a
Hopkins student, who was drunk,
tore an electrical fixture from the
side wall of the dance hall.

Teams Will Default
Teams which fail to appear for
competition at the time designated will default to their opponents. Should two teams which are
scheduled to oppose each other be
absent, they will both be defaulted
from the tournament.
The contestants will play contract bridge, while the old system
of rules will prevail in tallying
scores. The team that has amassed
the greater number of points after
three rubbers, in a match, will be
declared the winner.

HOPKINS PLACE, BALTIMORE

Spiked Shoe Plans
Interscholastic Meet
The Hopkins chapter of the
Spiked Shoe, National track and
field society, is sponsoring an inter scholastic cross-country meet
tomorrow in which teams from different sections of the Fast will
participate. Two local high school
teams representing the Baltimore
City College and the Baltimore
Polytechnic Institute have been
invited to enter, while the Bryant
High School of New York City has
accepted.
A bronze plaque will be awarded to the winning team and medals will be given to runners
placing first, second, and third in
the event.

DR. F. E. BAMBERGER
RETURNS FROM TOUR
OF WESTERN STATES
Studied Capability Of Children In Academic
Courses
SPOKE TO ASSEMBLY
IN WASHINGTON
Tour Was Made During
The Election
Period

Dr. Florence E. Bamberger, Professor of Education at Johns Hopkins University, chairman of the
Board of the College for Teachers,
recently returned from a tour of the
Western states, has found that the
general consensus of educational
opinion prevalent in the territory
included in her itinerary, is that
children incapable of mastering
academic courses should be given
vocational courses in their place.
By actual test, it has been proved
that although some pupils must attend school they are unable to receive passing grades in many academic subjects. Therefore, it is held
necessary for schools to include in
their curricula such vocational subjects as shop, and above all, music
and art to take care of these students.

Subjects Can Be Mastered

up the time of the teacher, leaving
her free to devote her entire time to
the other students which are interested in and can handle academic
subjects.
Dr. Bamberger was invited to
make the tour and to address eight
audiences by the Washington Association. After speaking in Washington, where she was received very
enthusiastically, she proceeded to
Portland, Oregon, at the request of
the Administrative Council, and the
Organization of
City School
Teachers.
Proposed Reform Measures

Made at election time, the tour
revealed to Dr. Bamberger several
proposed reform measures which
were being considered at that time.
Many states have initiative and referendum, and on Election Day an
initiative bill for a graded income
tax was referred to the people of
Washington, which also has a proposed equalization bill, to make the
tax more just by placing the heavier taxes on the wealthier counties.

The motion which was brought
up at the S.A.C. meeting Wednesday and which wil be voted on at
the next meeting to be held next
week reads:
Motion Brought Up

Students only in the College
of Arts and Sciences, School of
Engineering, and School of
Business Economics shall be
eligible for offices in•and membership in activities represented
in the Student Activities Council; any member of these three
schools who is expelled from
the University for any reason
by action of Student Council or
University officials shall automatically lose any post held in
any activity; and under the
New Plan a student shall be
eligible for office or membership until the completion of his
fourth year of undergraduate
residence.
This motion, if passed next
week, will automatically bar from
campus activities all students in
the College for Teachers and all
graduate students not under the
New Plan. Last April, the Council ruled out women from membership in Hopkins activities, but
this new ruling will bar both male
and female students n the College
for Teachers.
Not Part Of Undergrad School

It was pointed out that the College for Teachers is not regarded
as a part of the undergraduate
department q the University,
which officially consists 'of the
A.B., engineering, and business
economics schools, all of which
are exclusively male. Inasmuch
as the Student Activities Council
controls all campus activities in
the three undergraduate schools
and inasmuch as College for
Teachers and graduate students
do not pay the required ten-dollar
activities fee annually, it was decided to make a definite ruling as
to eligibility in Hopkins student
organizations governed by the
S.A.C.

Richard M. Haywood
Replaces Dr. Mustard
As a result of the death of Dr.
W. P. Mustard, formerly of the
Johns Hopkins University faculty,
Dr. Richard M. Haywood, also of
the University will take charge of
the former's Latin classes. Dr.
Haywood, who resides in Baltimore, received his Ph.D. from this
University in June, 1932.

Popularity Contest
AGAIN The Hullabaloo will conduct
its annual contest for the most popular
men in the freshman, sophomore, and
junior classes. Again, even for this obviously insignificant poll, politics will take
its place. Although we cannot see the
necessity for this popularity contest, we
ask that, if it is to be made actually
representative and fair, that every member of the three classes concerned cast his
ballot for the man whom he beleives deserves a place in the list of popular
undergraduates.
In the past, the contest was participated in by a decidedly small percentage
of each class. We urge that every freshman, sophomore, and junior vote for the
man in his class whom he believes has
done the most for his class and who is
generally regarded as a well-liked fellow.
The Hullabaloo editors should declare the
vote invalid if it is found that less than
two-thirds of each class casts ballots.

To the Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
I didn't agree with your editorial of November 4th. entitled
THE SURPRISE PACKAGE.
I had just finished a week of allnight sessions getting our magazine out on time, and let me tell
you it is one hell of a job. Its hard
for a raw editor to publish a publication for the first time especially with a new printing company.
I have just been through the mill
and I think you jumped on Miss
Howser a little too hard in your
editorial. If you could see how
generally "lousey" and machined
are the average run of publications, you would appreciate the
high standard of work that Miss
Howser has produced.
• As the publication of a magazine falls on the shoulders of one
person, as the editor has to go to
school as well as get it out, and as
Miss Howser had a number of
clever and novel features in the
magazine, I think your editorial
should have been one of encouragement and commendation instead of what it was.
Another thing. Even though the
publications here seem to habitusually disagree with your editorials,
still, I admire a person who comes
out and says what he thinks. The
University is never the loser when
such a person occupies the editor's chair. So here's to your editorial page—long may it rave.
CLARK HEIRONIMUS,
Editor, University of
Maryland Old Line.

A student came to Wetherford

At Creighton University an effective way of getting students
to class on time was accidently discovered by a janitor. He unwittingly placed a dearth of chairs in

Students of the Johns Hopkins
University who act in a manner
unbecoming gentTemen at the
dances sponsored by the Cotillion
Board and held in Levering Hall are
to be called before Student Council, it was announced yesterday.
It was indicated that on the
first offense, the student will probably be warned by Student Council to act gentlemanly in the future at the weekly dances in Levering. However, on the second offense, it was said, suspension of
the student will probably be ordered
by the Council.
The reason for this move was
not given, but it is believed that it
came in the wake of a recent incident in Levering Hall in which a
Hopkins student, who was drunk,
tore an electrical fixture from the
side wall of the dance hall.

Teams which fail to appear for
competition at the time designated will default to their opponents. Should two teams which are

absent, they will both be defaulted
from the tournament.

of rules will prevail in tallying
scores. The team that has amassed
the greater number of points after
three rubbers, in a match, will be
declared the winner.

HOPKINS PLACE, BALTIMORE

Spiked Shoe Plans
Interscholastic Meet
The Hopkins chapter of the
Spiked Shoe, National track and
field society, is sponsoring an inter scholastic cross-country meet
tomorrow in which teams from different sections of the Fast will
participate. Two local high school
teams representing the Baltimore
City College and the Baltimore
Polytechnic Institute have been
invited to enter, while the Bryant
High School of New York City has
accepted.
A bronze plaque will be awarded to the winning team and medals will be given to runners
placing first, second, and third in
the event.
